string.text: Tell me something interesting.

So, one time, I was with my team in the Garbage, and we were inspecting an old hangar. Everything was covered in dust and cobwebs. The place looked like shit. Suddenly, our detectors stopped working; our PDAs couldn't even show our own position. We made our usual formation: Sanyok in the front with us covering his back. Everything was going smoothly until all of a sudden, a bunch of metal beams fell from the roof. Sanyok managed to dodge them by some miracle. He fell, rolled back, and without even standing back up, started firing. The others were also scared shitless, and those idiots started shooting everywhere. Then Sanyok started yelling something about a creature sitting in the corner. There was nothing there when I looked, though.
 
Either way, it was clear that our operation was fucked. What happened after that was a total mess. Everyone panicked, shooting at nothing thinking they saw something. Two of them were really unlucky. One guy was walking on what appeared to be flat ground until he disappeared down a dark hole. The other guy was crushed by a heavy metal door; his spine was turned into mush. After a while, we finally got our shit together, turned on our psy-protection systems and tossed a smoke grenade towards every corner in hopes of luring the creature to the center. Well, it turned out this beast could fly, and while all of us were losing our shit on the ground, that bitch was just sitting up there watching us.
 
By the time we figured it out, it was too late. The beast knocked loose a few more steel beams from the scaffolding and splattered four of our guys. In the meantime, Sanyok heard ruffling in the rafters and fired in its direction without a second thought… Incredible reflexes. The beast screeched, and we started shooting where Sanyok landed his shot, bringing the bitch to the ground. Its bloodcurdling screeches left my ears ringing. Even after we ran out of ammo, we kept beating the shit out of the creature with anything we could find while Sanyok finished off the creature with his knife. When we were done, the beast laid splattered all over the floor.
That's one hell of a story.

You wanna know what I think? Or rather what I'm guessing? Maybe… Maybe all of this—everything around us—is just an experiment on humanity done by aliens. It kind of makes sense when you think about it… more than any of the other rumors people spread about this place. You know what's interesting? Why did the Zone emerge here out of all places? If this place was just some military experiment, then why isn't it better guarded and hidden? Are they checking which artifacts we want the most? What if these artifacts are actually bombs? Think about it: these artifacts are popping up in laboratories all over the world and in the hands of rich people. That would be cool, if some rich asshole would buy an artifact just to have it explode in his face. Ha ha ha!… Anyways, who knows what's really going on? The only people who really know are those who made it past the Red Forest. Yeah… They might know. Too bad they can't say anything. All they do is moan and drool all day.
Yeah. Anything is possible here.

We used to have this idiot with us. He was the laziest fuck to ever make it into the Zone. Whenever it was break time, he was the first one near the campfire, but when shit was about to go down, he couldn't be bothered to help out. Eventually, his laziness got him killed. His team spotted a controller, and he couldn't be bothered to get up from the warm campfire to save his own ass. The controller fried up his brains. People forget that this is the Zone, and you can't drop your guard here. Not even for a second. You need to pay attention to every noise, no matter how insignificant you think it is. You need to keep your guns locked and loaded and your grenades ready to go.\n \nAs for controllers, that's a different story altogether. They'll kill you before you even realize it. If you ever see a controller, even in the distance, get to cover immediately. They need to see you in order for them to start frying your brain, and even when they see you, they need a few seconds to concentrate. Once you're in cover, lay down some suppressive fire and throw a few grenades to hold back the controller and distract him. While it's busy figuring where all of that lead just came from, you run… Run as fast and as far away as possible.
Thanks for the story. I'll keep that in mind.

Yeah, somebody told me about something the other day and I can't remember what… Oh, yeah! Even though there's plenty of interesting stuff in the Zone—things that would make any scientist go crazy—foreign scientists won't go anywhere near the Zone. There are several reasons for it: first, why go yourself when you can hire a stalker for a small sum to do your dirty work for you? Second, a few years ago, there was actually this huge expedition from abroad that ended really badly… What, you haven't heard about it? That's strange…
 
Back when it happened, everybody in the Zone was talking about it. The expedition had thirty scientists from all over the world come here. They all had a shitload of money and the best gear out there. They had a special military unit escorting them, mind you. These weren't just regular grunts. I'm talking elite soldiers. They also hired some of our guides—three very experienced stalkers—to guide the way, and they took a BTR just for the hell of it. When they got back a week later, that BTR was wrecked to shit. It turned out the expedition was ambushed by bandit raiders who killed almost everyone from that expedition save for three people, two of our guides, and one foreign scientist. That same scientist was severely traumatized, and he had to be hospitalized in a mental institution. Right now, he's writing some kind of book about the Zone, and as for our guys, well, they just shrugged it off. Though, to be honest, I think they went through some trauma as well. One guy went off to the Red Forest and disappeared, and as for the other one, well, he just left the Zone. You're probably wondering how such a force could be taken down by a just a bandit ambush. That's not the whole story, though.
 
Have you heard anything about City 32? They say that's where the people from the expedition started to lose their mind. Some kind of mass hysteria spread from person to person, and everyone started losing their shit at the same time. Some even started scratching their throats out while others bashed their head on the wall. A few just outright shot themselves in the head. To make matters worse, a flock of large mutants showed up at the same time. Anyone who hadn't yet lost their mind fled to nearby houses and barricaded themselves in. Can you imagine the situation? It's midnight and pitch black outside, everyone loses their minds, and at the same time, a flock of powerful mutants is about to have you for dinner. Those who didn't lose their sanity spent the entire night locked in abandoned houses, waiting for morning to come.
 
And when the morning finally came, they tried to retreat. Some died in anomalies on the way back, and the rest encountered those bandits… I already told you how that ended up. Since then, no foreign scientists have dared to set foot in the Zone.
Thanks for the story.

So I was in the Dark Valley once, and I wanted to scan the area from somewhere high. I found a place where I could climb up: a chimney in a boiler station. So I entered the station, looked around, and the coast was clear. I found the chimney and started climbing up; there was already a ladder inside of it, and it was sturdy and comfortable, so climbing was easy. When I got to the top, I slowly lifted myself on top of the chimney to get a better look. And man, what a beautiful view… It felt like the entire Dark Valley was in my hands. I took out my binoculars and started scanning the area. Everything seemed clear.
 
Just as I was about to climb back down, it occurred to me that I should check what was happening beneath my feet. So I looked down around the station, and man, what do I see? A burer! Good thing I never went back down; I would've been dead for sure. Luckily for me, he didn't see me yet, or I wouldn't be here to tell you the tale. I wanted to snipe him with my AK, but the chimney I climbed up from was way too thin, and the AK was stuck on my back. As for trying to hit him with my Makarov, that was almost impossible. Plus, if I were to miss—and I *would* miss—the burer would've noticed me right away and killed me. So I was stuck there, thinking of what to do while the burer was messing around in the station, throwing some metal garbage around. This went on for about a minute until he froze in place, like he was listening in on something. Then the garbage started to move on its own, and the burer jumped back and put his hands to his head in a very awkward position. Suddenly, all the metal scrap in the building flew right into the burer, burying him underneath. I thought to myself, “I'm finally saved! That fucker is dead!”
 
But no… That pile of trash was only still for a few seconds before it started to move again. Eventually, the crap started to fly around in the air, and then it flew into a nearby wall, smashing it with immense force. Then the burer entered a different building, and I thought, “It's time to get the fuck out of here.” Just as started climbing down, I noticed the smell of smoke and started feeling intense heat. I look below me, and what do I see?… There's a fire inside the fucking chimney! I was starting to suffocate, so I climbed on top of the chimney, where I could at least get some air. Mind you, the smoke was still irritating my eyes. Good thing I always carry forty meter paracord with me, because I knew the only way out was to rappel down the chimney from the outside. I made a knot at the chimney and tied the rope around my waist and legs and slowly started to rappel down. The only thing on my mind was: “Please don't rip.” The rope was cutting into my hands as I made my way down, but it didn't rip. However, just as Murphy's law predicts, the rope was five meters too short, and I had no choice but to cut myself free and fall the rest of the way down. Thankfully, I didn't break anything, but I got torn up bad and busted up my right leg. I thought I ripped a tendon or something. I ran out of there as fast I could despite my leg hurting. Hell, I could've have won a gold medal with that speed.
Damn. That's intense.
Sorry, merc. I'm all out of stories.
Interesting story.
Come back another time. Perhaps I'll have something more interesting to tell you then…

Have you heard about Guide? The very first true stalker. He was the one who originally broke into the Zone, and he's still alive. People say he can take you to any place. You just need to name it. Now, finding him's a bit tricky; ain't no flyers around with his address… And he won't go with just anybody, either. From what I hear, he charges quite a bit. But if you find him and have enough cash, you can bet he'll take you where you need to go. Now that's someone I'd like to have a chat with. You can bet he's been beyond the Red Forest…
Interesting information. Thank you.

They say there's this one gang… People call them Shamans or Druids. It's said they don't use any electronic equipment at all; they want to stay close to the nature and stuff… Well, their reason for that is that the Zone reacts stronger to electronics. To all these “electromagnetic emissions” or something… They say it attracts monsters. Basically, they believe the Zone is like a living being, you know. Like, it's no good going into it with all these gadgets. If you're right in your mind, you'll get by fine without 'em. Doesn't stop them from carrying assault rifles, though… Guess the old teeth and nails aren't up to the task, eh? But then again, you don't hear a lot of stories about one of them kicking the bucket. Well, at least no more than us… So, who knows. Maybe they're on the right track there… They seem to be coming from the Belarusian side, though… I'd like to have a look at them one day and check out their pockets for some artifacts…
Thanks for the story.

Have you heard anything about the secret laboratories deep in the Zone? Some say they're still active. Nobody knows how the hell those labs are still operational, considering the fact that people can't survive there due to a lack of resources.\n \nHere's a theory: what if it's not people working there, but ghosts? I talked to this one guy. He hadn't been in the laboratory himself, but he did manage to catch some signals on his radio when he was in Yantar. He overheard a conversation about some kind of laboratory. Another guy swore that he saw some kind of transparent figure when he was in the Red Forest. It had some kind of upgraded SEVA suit, and it told him to get out of there and that he was interrupting some kind of important project, although it was awfully close to the Scorcher, so the whole thing could have been a hallucination for all we know… On the other hand, there are different kinds of mutations. Maybe the Zone turned those lab workers into something else.
No idea. Anything is possible in this hellhole.

Merc, you know anything about a group called “Interception”? It's a highly skilled special ops unit that goes on missions deep inside the Zone. They're nothing like the dipshits we have here in the Cordon; these are *real* pros. Not only do they go into the most dangerous places inside the Zone, but they stay there for months. They have a few hidden bases throughout the Zone, and they have plenty of stashes to boot. They also get supply drops via helicopter whenever they need it. Their commander's name is Gromov. I'm sure it's just a fake name.\n \nWhat, you don't believe me?! Belly caught their frequency once, though he turned it off immediately and ran away. This is top secret info, after all, and he could have been shot for just listening in on it. Man… Their pay, though. It's something else. If I had a third—no, a tenth—of their pay, I could just retire somewhere in Sochi. They even have some kind of special device that can locate mutants from afar, no matter what kind. Some say that they even travel into the center of the Zone while others say they've learned how to tame mutants. There are also rumors that these guys aren't military but rather highly gifted stalkers who signed a contract with the government. Duty knows all about those assholes, but they won't talk about them… They say it's all rumors. But trust me, they know better.
Don't move! Password, now!
Swordfish. You might want take your finger off that trigger before you hurt yourself, soldier.

Almost. Valerian's got a friend by the name of Belly. If he dies, we won't be disappointed, and you'll receive an additional bonus for dealing with him. After you complete the mission, contact me; I'll show you where to meet me again.
Understood. I'm going.
You're right. I take it you're Beast?
Yep. Let's get straight to the point.
Let us. You probably know about the stalker base that's by the railroad embankment. Well, we need to get rid of their leader—for good.
Can't you take him out yourself? I'd think all these soldiers could take on a stalker base.

We have our reasons. The thing is, we can't kill every stalker in that base. That'll attract too much attention. We need someone to eliminate Valerian without alerting anyone else. After that, the stalker base will fall apart on its own. I don't care how you take him out as long as you do it quickly. This has to been done in no longer than three days.
What's the pay?
Oh, don't worry about that. The pay is good. You'll get it once you finish the job—we don't pay in advance.
Is that all?

Someone must've heard the gunfire… They probably told their men that they were going to inspect the area around this vehicle station. This could cause some serious problems… What are your orders, Beast?
Don't get too worked up, Raven; these aren't Wolf's people. We already informed the rookie village about our arrival. We should find out who sent those men here. And also: get rid of the bodies.
I'll figure out what to do with them. Anything else?
We need to have a word with Wolf and his brother and see if they know anything about this.
Leave it to me. I'll talk to the stalkers and see what they know.
I'm with you. I need to talk to the old nut Sidorovich and make sure he doesn't find out that his contract is just a cover-up.
Yeah? What's so important? I told you people I was going to sleep and that you shouldn't wake me…
Get up, greenhorn. There's a job waiting for you.
Good plan. I'm in. But how am I supposed to gain their trust?

Do I have to babysit you? I don't care how you do it as long as it gets done. This conversation is over. After you deal with Valerian, get out of there and head to the bus station near the grain elevator. Got it?
Yes, Beast! I got it. I won't let you down.
I'm counting on you.
Oh, is that you, Beast? I didn't recognize you for a second. What's the job?
Gaining entry into that free stalker base.
Okay. I can do that. But what else?…
Interrupt me again and you'll get a bullet to the face. So, listen: once you're there, you need to assassinate the leader. His name is Valerian.
What a “job”… Do I look like I'm suicidal? The stalkers will kill me on the spot if I try anything.

Forgot about your debt already?! Don't you worry: no one's going to hurt you if you do everything right. You wanted to join the Syndicate, remember? This is your chance—the chance to prove you're not a lazy piece of shit, but a real soldier. What's more is that you'll finally pay off your debts and start earning some money. Sounds like a good deal, doesn't it?
Sounds good. How am I supposed to kill Valerian, though?

I'll tell you how. It's not too hard to pull off: you just have to gain the trust of the stalkers at the loner base. The rest is a cakewalk. At night, once Valerian goes to sleep, you'll sneak into his chamber when no one's looking and slit his throat. In the morning, you'll be long gone, and the stalkers will have no clue about who did it.
Hey, merc. I take it you lead the group at the vehicle station? Thanks for saving us from the bandits. You guys are real pros.
I was told that you want to join the Syndicate. Is that true?
Yessir. I'm tired of working my ass off for pocket change. I want to make some real money…
Very well. First, you have to do a job for me. A test of loyalty.
What do I need to do? I'm ready for anything.
I need you to make the mechanic leave his workshop. Distract him; lead him away. It doesn't matter how. Just get it done.

Hmm… I need to think. There might be one way, although he'll only be gone for a short while. I could take him to the bar and get drunk with him. Won't be the first time I get him under the influence. Will that work?
Yeah, as long as he empties more bottles than he can handle. Do you have enough cash?
Yeah, that won't be a problem.
All right. Get to it. Make sure he's passed out by nighttime.
You busy right now?
Not at the moment. What do you need?
Fine. It's your choice.
You need a hired muscle? Don't you have anywhere to go?
Do you need something to drink? I have a spare bottle of vodka that I've been keeping for a special occasion.
Aren't you tired? Don't you want to take a nap for at least an hour or two? I can ask the bouncer to come guard the workshop while you're gone.
Ain't that a strange question… No. I don't need to go anywhere, and if I did, I'd send someone else to do it.
No, thank you. I don't want any vodka right now. I don't wanna sit here drunk off my ass while there's a special contract waiting to be done.
Hmm… Why do you care, exactly? No. I don't want to sleep. I've already had eight energy drinks, and I have the whole night ahead to work on a special contract.
Whatever. It's your choice.
All right. It's your choice.
Greetings, mercenary. Did everything go according to plan?
Wait. Where's the lieutenant? Or… Are you the one who ordered the contract?
Yes. You've understood everything correctly. I wanted to meet you personally today. So, how did everything go?
Smooth as butter. Valerian and his friends are dead. Here's the proof.
At long last; that bastard got what he deserved. Good work, merc. A real pro. Tell me, do you know Scar? He's one of your men.
No. Don't know him.

That's too bad. He was a pro too. It's a shame he disappeared somewhere, but no one knows exactly where. I remember he helped me escape when those dirtbags had me behind bars. That Valerian sure caused a lot of problems; to me, to the stalkers, and to Sidorovich. I nearly ended up court-martialed because of that freak. The brass is up our asses to this day, and secret agents are always sticking their noses in everything. Anyway, enough about that. Here's your payment.
Pleasure doing business with you.
Hey, merc. Keep it down; we can't let anyone hear about this… Jackal has quite a serious mission for you. Don't screw it up.
So you're Coordinator?… I thought a secretive person like you would be doing something more serious than guarding a bar.

Spare me the jokes. You have no idea how hard it was to work undercover: for three weeks, I had to act like a regular security guard just so they would start trusting me. All so I could get the necessary info for you to carry out your contract.
All right, all right. I get it. Tell me, then, what Jackal has in store for me.

Okay, so, about a month ago, Sidorovich managed to get his hands on a locked black box that was retrieved from a fallen military helicopter, and someone's willing to pay good money for it. Your mission is to steal the black box. Sidorovich keeps it in his storeroom, located in here. Your main obstacle is Van, the technician. He works by the entrance to the storeroom, and you need to get rid of him to get through. Van always keeps consuming energy drinks, and he barely gets any sleep at all…\n \nOh, and one more thing: keep him alive. His death would attract too much attention. You only need to make sure he's passed out long enough for you to get the black box. Meanwhile, I'll make sure the door to the storeroom “accidentally” opens.
All right. If that's everything, I'm going to discuss this mission with my partner.
One more thing: this needs to be done tonight. So hurry up and do what you got to do.
Understood.
Not yet.
How's our mission going? Got the black box yet?
Yep. Here you go. Wasn't easy.

Never said it would be easy. You did your job well; something the Syndicate will take note of. I'll prepare an alibi for you in case Sidorovich gets suspicious. Also, Jackal called: he said that he has another mission for you. Ordered by the military…
What's the mission?

I have no idea myself. You'll get all the instructions from the client's representative. And remember—this is very important—in order for the military to identify you as their contractor, you'll need to say the password: “Swordfish.”
Understood. Give me the coordinates to the meeting point.
I've given you everything I have. Got no more info.
What's up, Creature?! He he… So, how's Sidorovich's contract going?
Forgot your commanding officer? Call me “Creature” again and I'll snap your neck like a twig.

Yeah, yeah. Sure. You should probably remember what Jackal said about that… You remember, right? Anyway, back to the point: I called you here for a reason. You see, Jackal's tired of waiting for you to carry out his personal contract, so you're no longer in charge here. You, Creature, will drop all your current affairs and start executing his mission.
Just like that, huh? Who'd he put in charge?

Me… for now. But once Sidorovich's contract is done, Jackal will pick a new, permanent commander. I just don't understand, though: why the hell did he pick a clown like you in the first place? You couldn't even secure a good place for your team, not to mention how awfully you deal with all your contracts.

Me… for now. But once Sidorovich's contract is done, Jackal will pick a new, permanent commander. I just don't understand, though: why the hell did he pick a clown like you in the first place? You couldn't even secure a good place for your team, not to mention how awfully you deal with all your contracts.
That's none of your business, Obscurant. Now tell Jackal that I'll get his contract done. I'll find Vector and kill him.
Hey, merc. What's up? Got Sidorovich's package?
Yeah. I have it. Pay me first, then you'll get the package.
Heh, how mindful of you… Don't worry. I'm not like Sidorovich. When I say that I'm going to pay someone, I pay them. Give me the package, and I'll give you the money.
Here you go.

Okay. Take your money. Take note of the fact that I've paid you twice the amount Sidorovich asked me to; I have my reasons. I have a feeling I'll be stuck here for a while. Valerian has disappeared somewhere, and it's uncertain whether or not he'll return at all. *Someone* has to keep things in order here.\n \nAnyways, our trader needs your help. He asked us to send you over to him. Go talk to him and see what he wants. He should pay you more than I have.
Okay, I'll see what he wants.
Nice to see you, merc. Any news?
One of our squads has been radio silent. I fear something happened to them. I don't have anyone else to send, so will you lend me a hand?
Of course I can lend you a hand… for a price.
God, you mercenaries. Almost forgot who I'm talking to… We don't have a lot of time to negotiate, Beast, so could you find those men ASAP? We'll discuss the payment after your return.
I'll hold you to it. Where do I need to go?

They went over the hill, toward one of our outposts, but the problem is, that area was overrun with bandits not long ago. I see your gear is quite advanced, unlike ours, so a few bandits should be a piece of cake. I'll mark the area on your PDA.
Got it. I'll head there now.
Any news, merc? Did you find the missing squad?
Get out of here, merc!

Greetings, merc. I take it you received my message? I'm Wolf. To tell you the truth, we're not really happy about your presence in these parts… I know you're here on Sidorovich's contract and all, but let's try and make each others' lives easier. Try not to meddle in anything that doesn't concern you or your group in the Cordon. Understood?
I'll get going.
Not yet, I'm on it.
Great job! Zokhan told me the whole story about you saving him and his entire squad. I would never have thought a group of mercenaries would rescue our boys.
No need to thank me. Just pay me.
No. I feel I should, since mercs don't care about anyone but themselves, from what I've seen. But you're different. By the way, I contacted Sidorovich; he said he's ready to take you.
All right. Then I'll go see Sidorovich.
Wait a minute. Here's the payment for a job well done. I don't have a lot of money on me, so here's an artifact as well. Hope it'll be useful. Big thanks to you and your men for the help!
Is that all?
Yeah. Thanks again for helping us. You can go about your business.
Understood. I'm Beast, and this is Raven. Thanks for the warm welcome. How's Sidorovich?
All right. I'll go see Sidorovich.
Hello, merc. What do you need?
Sadly, the old fart's doing all right, but you'll have to wait a while. He's got some important business to attend to, and he won't let anyone in his bunker for the time being.
When can I see him?
Not anytime soon, that's for sure. Sidorovich likes to take his sweet time with his business.
We'll be on our way then. Please inform me when Sidorovich has a moment.
Wait, wait. Hold up. Can you help me with something?
Tell me what that “something” is, and then we'll see.

Listen, Beast: I didn't call you here just to chit-chat. Not everyone's happy about the fact that Jackal assigned you as our acting commander, especially Obscurant. He flew off the handle when he heard the news, and he's not the only one who wanted your position. Just be careful—who knows what goes on in that man's head. He's dangerous and unpredictable.
Thanks for your concern, but I can handle it.

Of course. Just be aware of the general consensus. If Jackal made you the commander, he must've had a specific reason despite a number of individuals disagreeing with his decision. A few well-done contracts will help strengthen your reputation, though.\n \nBy the way, our watch is reporting that an unknown group of stalkers is heading toward the base. They've ignored our warnings not to come here. Either way, it's your call on what to do with them.
All right. I'll talk to them. Is that all?

No. That's not all: the people here won't be happy about our arrival here. If we want to stay on good terms with the locals, we shouldn't poke our noses into everything. The only place we're welcome in right now is the rookie village, but you already know that.\n \nThat's about it. I won't keep you any longer.
Thanks for the briefing. I'll go deal with our visitors.
You the one in charge here? What the hell are you doing in the Cordon? Last time I checked, mercenaries weren't allowed around here, right?
You out of your minds? Get out of here while you can. The less you know, the better—ever heard of that saying?

Listen up, merc: either you tell me what the hell you're doing here or things are going to get ugly real quick. This isn't your territory, and you don't make the rules here. If I were you, I'd fess up right now.
Is that a threat? What are you three gonna do against an entire group?
We'll slaughter you all if it comes to that. Now tell us what you're doing in the Cordon! You're starting to piss me off…
And you've already pissed me off. You bastards shouldn't have poked your noses into our business. This is your last chance to get out of here while you're still breathing.

Don't tell us what to do, you hired gun piece of shit… You come into our territory, snooping around, making these demands, and breaking the peace—and now you want to start bossing us around, too? This is our territory, and you're the ones who are getting out of here!
Too bad. I gave you a chance.
Hey, there, merc! What are you doing here?
I could ask you the same thing. What are you doing here?
A psy-dog, confound the thing. I'm not giving you the tail—it's mine—but you can keep everything else. Do we have a deal, merc?
Deal! Let's go.

Me? I'm hunting a mutant. I've been tracking this creature all the way from the Agroprom, and no matter what I try, it always manages to slip away. This mutant is dangerous, but I'm on a mission from the scientists at Yantar, and I have to complete it. So anyway, I was sneaking up to it here as it was eating a dead stalker and the second it saw me, it ran away. That poor stalker suffered a terrible death.
I was looking for that stalker. Did you search his body?
I searched him. There wasn't much to take, so I left him alone. I'm just here trying to figure out where that mutant went.
When you were searching him, did you run across a flash drive?
So that's why you're here… Sorry to break it to you, but there was no flash drive.
But?
There's a chance that the mutant swallowed the flash drive along with the guy's leg. Since we don't have any better option, I suggest we start looking for it.
Tell me what type of mutant we're hunting here.
Phew! That thing sure was strong. I can finally wrap up this mission and go see the scientists. How about you? Did you find your flash drive?
Yeah. You were right: the mutant ate it. Good thing it didn't start digesting anything.
Ha. It takes a long time to digest a flash drive, so I wouldn't worry about that.\n \nI have to get moving; need to haul my ass all the way to Yantar now. Farewell, merc, and thanks for the help.
Farewell.
Yeah? What do you need?
Wanna chit-chat a bit, while there aren't any clients to bother you?
Sure. What do you want to know?
Tell me about yourself.

I've been buying and selling shit since before the fall of the Soviet Union. I was one of those “evil speculators,” and I used to buy and sell serious shit; the real deal… until I got caught and thrown in jail, that is. After that, I made friends with some professional crooks in jail. Started running with them when I got out. Got locked up again for another three years, and when I got out, the Soviet Union was already gone. Once I was free, it felt like a totally different world that I couldn't find my place in. For a long time, all I did was small time work, and I was barely able to scrap together a living… Then the Zone appeared, and I found my place here. Everything here is like the old days, and with my experience in trading, I'm always able to make a good living here.
Cool. Tell me something else.
All right. I got to go.
What do you think about Logopedist?

I'll tell you this: Logopedist won't stay on top for long. My gut tells me Koba will make him disappear. Logopedist keeps showing off, and by the looks of it, he thinks he's untouchable. What's worse is, he can't notice the fact that a good chunk of us are getting sick of his shit. Remember, though: I'm telling you this because I trust you, and this conversation needs to stay between us. By the way, if you find anything interesting about either Logopedist or Koba, bring it here. In the end, though, it doesn't matter who's in charge. I'll always be here.
Tell me about the Garbage.

Yeah, the guys weren't happy about moving to the Garbage. Back then, nobody even thought about going there. They avoided those radioactive heaps of junk like the piles of shit that they are. That was, until a few stalkers decided to start digging through those mounds of junk, and after that, everyone flocked there. At first there was massive chaos there, but then the bandits came, and they put everyone in their place. I think the Zone should be like any other “Zone,” with a clear hierarchy and firm rule, either instilled by cops or by bandits. Hedgehog here also pays to keep the peace around here, and we get a good cut out of everything. We need to eat too. Maybe one day, I'll visit the Garbage myself. Even though this place isn't half bad, there's some serious cash flowing through the Garbage right now.
What's the latest news in the Zone?

I don't like that expression—“latest news.” If I were you, I would stop asking around before the “latest news” becomes your last. Even though the people here aren't that bad, something really fucked up happened not long ago. A stalker came in here. Scared shitless, pale, and his hands were shaking. He and his friend were running away from a group of poltergeists, and they ran into a flock of rodents. I think the waves of hairless rats were so terrible, the guy got scared and shot his friend a few times in the back. So then the rodents, instead of running after him, decided to just eat his dead bro. After coming back, the guy drank his second bottle then started crying his heart out. “Igor, you gave me your last medkit that one time, and I killed you like the last piece of shit on earth.” He was crying all day long, and when the night came, he hung himself on his belt.
Yeah, not that interesting, really.
Whatever you say.
Why is this place called “Bar number ninety-two”?

It's simply because the number ninety-two is uranium in the periodic table, which is usually used in nuclear reactors. I think it was Sidorovich's idea… Hey, you gotta admit it's pretty original. Sidorovich and I should copyright this name and sell it to some big shot from Moscow. He'd then open a bar by the same name with some Zone decorations: a few artifacts, a stuffed rodent, some worn out chimes, and a tooth from a pseudogiant. That place would bring a lot of clients. Sid and I would get rich just by getting a small fraction of the business's earnings.
So, Shaman, is this enough muscle for you?
Yep, this is enough. Thanks for your help. I'll pay fifteen hundred for each guard, just like we agreed.
Yep, this is enough. Thanks for your help. I'll pay twenty-five hundred for each guard, just like we agreed.
Yep, this is enough. Thanks for your help. I'll pay thirty-five hundred for each guard, just like we agreed.
Pleasure doing business with you. Bye.
Sidorovich said that you might have a job for me. What problem do you have?
Problem? I don't have any problem. I just need some more muscle in my bar. Can you help with that?
All right. Twenty-five hundred for each guard.
All right. Thirty-five hundred for each guard.
No. I won't lower the rent price.
In that case, no deal. Forgot about this conversation; I guess I'll have to make do with what I've got.
Whatever you say.
All right. that's an affordable price. We need four people with their own gear, since I have none to spare.
Deal. They'll be here shortly.
I can send a few people your way. For some cash, of course. It'll take some time for them to arrive, though.
All right. Money's not a problem. How much for each head?
Fifteen hundred for each guard.
Twenty-five hundred for each guard.
Thirty-five hundred for each guard.
Five thousand for each guard.
Mmm… That's too much for me, merc. Could lower the price a bit?
Ugh… Fine. Fifteen hundred for each guard.
Tell me about the Zone.

Do I look like one of those eggheads? They're the ones who have the Zone under a microscope. Me? I don't know much about this place. I'm only interested in the money-making here, and that's what I'm doing. Hopefully, after a few years, I'll a buy a piece of land near a lake and a large villa.
I'd like to rent a bed.
No problem. It'll be twenty-five hundred for a day. I don't rent them out for any longer than that. If you need it for an additional period of time, come back later and pay me for the next day.
All right. Here you go.
Nah, I'll pass.
Excellent! The bedroom is down the hallway you came from, to the left. Your bed is located to the right of the entrance. There's also a footlocker by the bed that you can use for storage.
Whatever you say. It's your choice.
Greetings, merc! You've just entered the bar with the biggest assortment of food and drinks in the whole Zone. Welcome, and enjoy your stay.
Hey, merc. Fancy a drink?
Can you turn off the radio?

Yeah, sure I can. Just not for free. A lot of people here stay to listen to the tunes, so you're gonna have to compensate them. Five hundred rubles, to be exact.\n \nI'll turn off the radio once you pay, but keep in mind that once you leave the bar, I'm turning it back on.
Fine. Here are your five hundred rubles.
I changed my mind.
Pleasure doing business with you!
Whatever. Your call.
Can you turn on the radio?
Changed your mind, eh? No problem! Here you go!
There. I turned it on.
Listen to your heart's content. I don't mind. But if you want me turn it off again, you're gonna have to pay.
Hey!
I'm here to collect my order.

Here's your Steppe Eagle. It turned out trickier than I thought. Some kind of pistol buff showed a lot of interest, but I barely snatched it in time. See for yourself: a hand-crafted gun. Components are all adjusted with unmatched precision. Ever wonder what a perfect sniper pistol would look like? Well, this is it. You owe me twenty-eight hundred extra.
Okay, here you go.
There you go. Nice doing business with you.
I don't have that much on me.
Okay, I'll hold the gun for you a while. I hope you find the money soon.
I don't want to buy this.
If you refuse to collect the order, I won't be able to rely on you next time around. I'll have to include the risk estimate in the price and ask for a larger advance.
Still, I will not be collecting this order.
All right, suit yourself.
I'll think about it.
Sure, that's up to you. I'll hold the gun for you for a while.
Here's your ultra high-accuracy Steppe Eagle. You owe me twenty-eight hundred extra.

Behold the Alpine: a real beauty. You can rest assured this pistol is one of a kind in the whole Zone. A unique model, very limited issue commissioned for a single special unit. It wasn't easy to obtain, I even had to involve one of my overseas associates. An expanded magazine, extra hard steel barrel, receiver made of extra strong polymers. Add the remaining twenty-eight hundred and this baby's yours.
Here's your Alpine pistol with an expanded magazine. Add the remaining twenty-eight hundred and this baby's yours.

Lookit, this is March. The pistol belonged to a mercenary called Wolfhound. A compact high-caliber shooter with short blowback and a lightened bolt. Wolfhound was one hundred percent scum, but he knew his weapons; gotta give him that. They say his favorite trick was to blow all four of his victims' limbs off and then his head, before it hit the ground. Anyway, that'll be twenty-eight hundred.
Here's your rapid-fire March pistol. You owe me twenty-eight hundred extra.

Here you go: Cutter, a submachine gun. Let me say it right off: don't you mind the appearance. It's a brand new model; not in serial production yet. It's a prototype; fresh from the armory. The designers aimed to make a new-generation close-range weapon: a combination of high caliber, rapid fire, and accuracy. So that'll be eight thousand extra.
Yes, here's Cutter, a rapid-fire submachine gun. That'll be eight thousand extra.
Here's a fine specimen: Carabineer. A true army shotgun. Capable of automatic fire while providing good anti-recoil thanks to a balanced, shock-free system. Add eight thousand and it's yours.
Here's Carabineer, an automatic shotgun. Add eight thousand and it's yours.

I reckon this is just what you need. Eliminator, a latest development. The whole batch was supposed to be shipped to Central Africa, but I got a “sample” as a special favor from friends. An automatic shotgun with a large magazine and an excellent rate of fire. Yours for only eight thousand.
Sure. Automatic shotgun Eliminator, with an extended magazine. For eight thousand.

Sure. Behold Storm, a submachine gun and grenade launcher in one. This prototype is a modified version of a conventional weapon designed for special units operating in the Zone. Technical innovation at its best from our Slavic brothers… Add sixteen thousand and it's yours.
Sure. Here's Storm, a submachine gun and grenade launcher in one with an extended magazine, for an extra sixteen thousand.

Here it is: GP37, a new-generation assault rifle. Accurate, reliable, and convenient with a built-in optical scope. It was previously owned by a UN observer. Their group was sent to the Zone to investigate. However, the situation turned for the worse… Sixteen thousand and the rifle is yours.
Here it is: GP37, a new-generation assault rifle. The price is sixteen thousand.

Just a sec. Here's a modular FT-200M rifle, the brainchild of Belgian gunmakers. Accurate, all-purpose, handy for both righties and lefties, comes with an optical scope and a grenade launcher. I got it from some unlucky UN observers… That'll be sixteen thousand extra.
Here's a modular FT-200M rifle. That'll be sixteen thousand extra.

Here's Tide. Based on a silent sniper rifle, it was specifically designed for military units to fight zombies. The Tide sacrifices rate of fire in favor of stopping power, allowing the sniper to pick off zombies one by one without disclosing his location. However, it then became clear that stalkers alone would be enough to stop zombies at the Barrier, so the rifle never reached mass production. This baby's yours for an extra sixteen thousand.
Here's Tide, a silent sniper rifle with increased stopping power. Add an extra sixteen thousand and enjoy.

Here. This is an SVU2-A, a short sniper rifle with an increased rate of fire. I bought it off Mac, the legendary Freedom guard. He swore there are no others like it in the whole Zone. It's an exclusive item, at least in these parts. It'll be sixteen thousand extra.
Yeah. SVU2-A, a short sniper rifle with an increased rate of fire. It'll be sixteen thousand extra.

Sure, just look at the Lynx here. Hand-crafted by a local expert. He's deceased now, so there won't be any copies. It looks just like any other rifle, but take it out for some target practice and you'll feel all the difference. It's got a perfect combination of accuracy and stopping power. Add the remaining sixteen thousand and this baby's yours.
Yeah, Lynx: a sniper rifle with increased accuracy and power. Add sixteen thousand and it's yours.

Look here. I managed to get everything off my list: a CS-3a with a helmet. The helmet is nothing special on its own, but it allows for installing a mobile tactical system, which includes a high-quality night vision system and an active infrared sensor. Now, the CS-3a armor is a real beauty. Excellent protection from bullets and anomalies is a rare feature indeed in a suit as light and mobile as this one. The whole thing will cost you thirty-two thousand.
Yeah. A set consisting of a CS-3a suit with a tactical helmet. Thirty-two thousand and it's yours.

Specially for you, a SEVA suit. Everything just like you ordered: a closed-cycle respiratory module, thermal resistant, protective electrical circuit, and outer-surface anticorrosion materials. Plus several built-in artifact containers as a bonus. A must-have suit for any stalker. Toss in twenty-four thousand like we agreed and it's yours.
Here. A SEVA suit. The price is twenty-four thousand, like we agreed.

There it is, a combat exoskeleton as large as life. The best protection you can get in the Zone from bullets, claws or grenade fragments, with the exception of armored vehicles. But it also takes after armored vehicles in that it relieves your weight burden… within reason, of course. Forty-eight thousand and it's yours, warts and all… err… by that I mean batteries and servomotors.
There it is, a combat exoskeleton as large as life. Forty-eight thousand and it's yours.
I want to place an order.
No problem. What do you need?
A pistol.
Of course. It'll be thirty-five hundred, of which I will require an advance payment of seven hundred.
Okay, here you go.
I'll get in touch with you as soon as the order is ready.
I don't have the money on me.
Well, please come back when you've got the cash.
You know, I've changed my mind.
Fine. If you finally decide to make an order, I'm always here.
You're not a very reliable customer, so the pistol will cost you forty-two hundred. And I will require an advance payment of fourteen hundred.
I'm afraid the best pistols have already sold out. If you want the regular stuff, Owl's the man to see.
A close-range weapon.
Sure thing. The price is ten thousand, and I'll need two thousand of that in advance.
You refused to pick up your last order… So this one will cost you twelve thousand, and I'll need four thousand of that in advance.
Hrm… You know, I probably can't help you there. The demand is too high.
An assault weapon.
Something high-caliber and with rapid fire capability, okay… The regular price is twenty thousand, with a four thousand advance payment. What do you say?
You're a tough customer. I'll have to charge you twenty-four thousand and I need eight thousand paid in advance. Deal?
Right now is a bad time… the military are making things hot at the Cordon. Someone attacked their outpost the other day, which made them even more difficult to deal with.
A sniper weapon.
For you, I can get the best for only twenty thousand, but you'll have to pay me four thousand in advance.
Working with you entails a certain amount of risk… I can try to arrange your order for twenty-four thousand, but you'll need to make an eight thousand down payment.
Sorry, this type of weapon is hard to come by right now. My contact for sniper stuff is… let's say he's indisposed.
An armored suit.
Yeah, I can think of something… suitable. It'll cost you forty thousand, but you'll have to pay me eight thousand in advance.
Yeah, I can think of something… suitable. You refused to collect your last order, so the price will be forty-eight thousand and you'll have to pay me sixteen thousand in advance.
I won't be able to do any better than the last suit I got for you. That one was both unique and top of the line.
A suit with a closed-cycle respiratory module.
That's a tall order… Won't be easy to obtain, not by a long shot. I can try to get one of these babies for thirty thousand, but I have to ask for a down payment of six thousand.
You let me down on the last order, so I have to think twice this time. I can try to get one of these babies for thirty-six thousand, but I have to ask for a down payment of twelve thousand.
I bent over backwards to get the last one. Don't think I'll be able to repeat that.
A mercenary exoskeleton.

You must have given this choice a lot of thought. I can get my hands on a combat version, but it'll cost you sixty thousand. Expensive, I know, but well worth it. Keep in mind I'll need twelve thousand of that paid right now.
You didn't treat me very nicely on the last order, so this one'll set you back seventy-two thousand. Keep in mind I'll need twenty-four thousand of that paid right now.
No way. Since they closed the manufacturing plant, vacant exoskeletons are typically found only on corpses… That's just not my method.
Nothing right now.
Sorry, my shop is closed at the moment. Temporary difficulties with order shipments…

Hello there, Beast! If you need any weapons or gear, you've come to the right place. I offer you rare models, prototypes, and unique weapons in addition to some elite equipment; namely, some recent combat suit designs. Each order is handled by me personally, so high quality is guaranteed!
Hello. Would you like to place an order?
Hello.
Your order will be delivered very soon.
The order is finished. Please come to collect it.
Sidorovich asked me to find this courier. I didn't expect to find him dead. My sympathies, man.
Damn… He was one of the good ones; I went through a lot of shit with the guy. You'd think this would be the last place he'd die… The Cordon is the safest place in the Zone, and yet here he is…
Did you see who killed him?
Did you find anything else interesting, hunter?
Did you search his backpack?
All right. Did you know this stalker?
I found a PDA in his backpack, but it's locked. Do you know anyone who can hack it?

Nope. I don't know, nor have I seen who did it. I accidentally caught his signal when I was walking by, and he wasn't answering. I came here to check it out. I thought he might've pressed the SOS button by accident or something.
Yeah. This is a sad turn of events, but what's done is done.
Those bastards! Why would somebody do such a thing? Fuck… I told him not to take that damn job—that it was too risky—but, no, he just had to go and get himself killed… Ugh… Anyway, what do you need?
No. I haven't searched his backpack yet. I doubt there's anything valuable there.
Yeah, I knew him well, and I used to help him with his courier jobs from time to time. He was a good, kind-hearted stalker. I don't know why someone would kill him.
I don't know for sure, but I think Van could help with that. You should ask him.
Well, I'll go search him. He might have something that I need.
Gotcha.
All right. I'll ask him.
All right. That's all I needed to know. Good luck out there.
Did you know this guy?
Yeah, I knew him well, and I used to help him with his courier jobs from time to time. He was a good, kind-hearted stalker. I don't know why someone would kill him.
Who could have done this?
text in default
Sidorovich, some say you trade valuable information. Is that true?
Yeah… Never mind.
What can you tell me about Shaman?
Five hundred rubles, and I'll tell you everything I know.
Okay, here.

Shaman's a good guy. He used to be in some kind of special forces unit or something… He is nowhere near like Wolf, but he still knows his way around the Zone, and he's been around for more than a year now. Most stalkers can learn a lot from him, especially new ones. He's a real leader, and he keeps all the stalkers here in line and makes sure that they all watch each other. He's also a good strategist. He always knows how to solve problems, even very complicated ones. All in all, he's a good stalker, and I'm glad he's here.
Do you know anything about Mark?
Any whim for your money. It's five hundred rubles.
What do you know about Borland?
Depends on what information you're looking for… Tell me what you need to know, and then I'll see if I can help you.
My price for such information is always the same: five hundred.
Got change for a thousand?

According to rumors in the Zone, Borland wasn't a soldier, nor was he a scientist. Rather, he was a thirty-two-year-old professional racer. Due the ongoing mess in his home country, every race track and stadium was closed, and Borland was forced to find something else to do with his life. He was quick to grasp that the only place for him is the Zone. All of his talents are useful here. His dexterous eyes and hands, his ability to remain cool in dangerous situations, and his stamina all serve him well here in the Zone. Borland had the ability to find the solution to any problem on the fly—no matter how tough—and he had a great sense of time and distance. Really, the Zone was nothing new for him; it was all the same, except the stakes were higher.
I heard about this guy named Fang. You wouldn't happen to know anything about him?
Oh, Shroud! That's a really good question! I just so happen to know a lot about him. Give me five hundred rubles, and I'll tell you something.
I am all ears.

Fang is a legendary stalker. He was part of Strelok's group. You could say he was the “muscle”; he would take care of anything combat related. He was a terrific shot, and more than that, he was also very capable in engineering various gadgets. He upgraded his own exoskeleton and made it the best piece of armor the whole Zone. Too bad he disappeared somewhere. Nobody knows the exact location. Some say that he died, while others say that he simply left the Zone. I can't tell you for sure. I simply don't know.
Do you know anything about Strelok's group? How about Ghost?
Five hundred rubles…
Here.
What do you know about Wolf? Who is he, and how did he get here?

Ghost was something of a spy: he could sneak anywhere without anyone catching even a whiff of him. He wasn't called Ghost for nothing. Too bad he died in the underground laboratory beneath Yantar… He was a good stalker. Perhaps even one of the best.
Information is a precious commodity. Pay five hundred rubles, and I'll spill the beans.
Whatever you say…
Don't you think that's a tad too much? I'll pass.

Sergey Yekimov—Wolf, that is—and his family were always in a bad shape. His wife left him around the same time that he got fired from his job. He'd spend days drinking his life away at some pub, but after his brother, Peter, found himself in some trouble too, things changed. Peter was beaten up by some local gang. Got beaten to a pulp, just barely clinging on to life. As you might've guessed, Wolf didn't just stand idly by. He tracked down the ones resposible for the attack, and just a week after the beating, he shot every single gang member dead. After that, Wolf fled into the Zone and started building up his reputation. He used to conduct deep raids into the Zone, but chose to stay in the Cordon later on, where the atmosphere is much calmer, with only the military patrolling the border and rookies waiting to be trained. That's how Wolf became the legendary rookie leader we all know.
Do you know anything else?
All right. Thanks for the info.
All right, Beast, what are your orders?
Hey. What's up?
I need you to patrol the base.
Sit back for a while. I don't have any work for you right now.
Get back to base.
Never mind.
I want to hire some extra security.
Tell me where you need the guard so I can assign him his post right away.
Excellent. Some extra guards have been sent from the nearest outpost.
I want to hire some extra security.
Very well. The price for the soldier is twenty-five hundred, and you'll have to pay out of your own pocket since you're the leader. So what do you say? Are you hiring?
Very well. The price for the soldier is twenty-five hundred, and you'll have to pay out of your own pocket since you're the leader. So what do you say? Are you hiring?
Very well. The price for the soldier is twenty-five hundred, and you'll have to pay out of your own pocket since you're the leader. So what do you say? Are you hiring?
Yeah. Here's the cash.
Yeah. Here's the cash.
Yeah. Here's the cash.
Administration building, second floor.
Near the tunnel leading to the Dark Valley.
Yard, south entrance.
Yard, north entrance.
All right, I need to go.
Very well. The price for the soldier is twenty-five hundred, and you'll have to pay out of your own pocket since you're the leader. So, what do you say? Are you hiring?
Yeah. Here's the cash.
No. I changed my mind.
Hey, Beast! What's up?

Coordinator will be waiting for you in Bar ninety-two. Jackal never described his appearance to me, but he did say that he'll approach you first. Man, this mission is probably going to be worth it. This contract that Jackal's giving us is serious.
What types of jobs did you do before this one?
Small shit, for the most part. Nothing too serious. The pay wasn't that good, either.
All right. I'll go meet this Coordinator. The more info I can get about this mission, the better.
Hey, Beast! Got any work for me?

Yes. Contact Jackal and ask him to send four fighters our way. Tell him we need the soldiers for a security job at the bar and that if it goes as planned, our pay will be good. In the meantime, though, we won't be paying for them.
Jackal won't be too happy with sending troops without an advance payment, but he'll go through with it as long as the pay is good in the end. What about the briefing? What should we tell the troops?
They just need to guard the bar in the rookie village. Just send them there when they arrive here.
All right. I'll do that. Once the mercs arrive, I'll contact you.
Right, then. See you later.
Hey, Beast! What's up?
No. I've changed my mind.
Excellent. Jackal just dispatched a few extra guards from the nearest outpost.
All right. I got to go.

Hey, Beast. There aren't many of us in the Cordon right now. Jackal's refusing to send us reinforcements without some extra payment, but if you want, you can hire some more people for a small fee. They'll be here to protect our temporary base, and we'll need it. Who knows what the stalker bastards will try next… So, if you provide the funds, I can radio Jackal and get us more men.
Hey, Beast! What's up?
Greetings, Beast! Bizon told me that Sidorovich transferred the money for the contract. Any news about it? Is there any work for me?
There is. Radio Jackal and tell him that the trader needs two men to guard his bunker. I have no manpower to spare. I think he'll understand.
I'll get on it right away. Oh, by the way, I almost forgot: Jackal told me that Coordinator's ready to meet you and that he has a new job for us. He told me you should see him personally.
That's probably the secret mission Jackal told us about… All right. Where is this Coordinator waiting for me?
Hey, Beast. Vulture told me you've talked to Coordinator. So what's the job?
We need to “borrow” something from Sidorovich's warehouse, but to get there, we have to neutralize the mechanic.

All right. I'm sure we'll come up with something… Also, I found out about our three guests that visited us a while ago. They were Valerian's men, and they were sent to observe us and collect intel. I guess they were too cocky for that job.
I see. That means they weren't here on Sidorovich's orders. We don't need more problems.

At least we tried to negotiate with them. Not our fault they were so aggressive… Oh, the stalker we saved at the bandit outpost, Raccoon, asked to join the Syndicate. I turned him down; gave him the regular “you're too green” response.
You did the right thing. Though, having a mole in the rookie village wouldn't be a bad idea.
Why would we pick *that* stalker? He could compromise our whole operation, and we would have to spend days unfucking the mess afterwards.
Relax. I have a plan. Raccoon could help us with our current mission.
And what would he do? He won't even do so much as touch Valerian. He'll just get shot down by the guards… What the hell are you thinking?
We just need to force Valerian out of the base. We could easily ambush them and finish the job quietly. Easy as that.

So you want to use that rookie as bait?… Ah. I get it now: Valerian will find out that we sent an assassin after him, after which he'll try to escape. Then we kill him while he's away. That's actually a good plan. This could totally work.
Exactly. Tonight, we'll see if my plan works out. I've told Vulture to send two men to keep an eye on the stalker base.
All right. And what will you do now?
I'll head back to base and wait for a signal from the recon team. Until then, we won't be making any move.
Hey, Beast. Got new orders?

Raven, I need you to take two fighters and get to the tunnel leading to the Dark Valley ASAP. Valerian took the bait. He's going to try and escape through the tunnel, and we're going to ambush him there.
Got it. Heading out now. You with us?
Yes. Let's go.
Not now. I'll stay here for a bit.
You should probably talk to the hostage first.
You're right.
This checkpoint is ours. The guys will hold it until we… well, *you* decide what to do next. We can head back to the village now. What about those stalkers? Can they walk?
Yeah. They're fine. Listen: my sniper rifle needs some adjustments. When we get back to the village, take it to the technician. See if he can do anything.
Gotcha. Are we heading back to the the village?
Yeah. Let's go.
Just wait for a moment. I need to check something.
So are you ready to go?
Yeah. Let's go.

We're in position, Beast. Another group of ours just arrived in the Cordon; they'll be joining us in the assault. Everyone's ready to go. The bandits won't know what hit 'em. Before we strike, though, can I ask you a question?
Excellent. Ask away, Raven.
Are you sure it's worth it? Risking our guys for a couple of nobodies? I doubt Wolf is paying us a fortune for this.

I'm not really sure, but this is our best option at the moment. By carrying out this contract and saving those men, the people around here will start to trust and recognize us. We need a good reputation.
Got it. So, we're doing this… How's the sniper spot I picked? I thought it matched your request. Plus, I couldn't find anything better, so…
The position is perfect, Raven. Ideal for trying out my new sniper rifle.
I'm glad it suits you. Now let's go over our plan one more time: I help our guys distract the bandits while you snipe them off one by one from up here. That right?
That's our plan, all right. Now let's do this.
I need medical assistance.
Let's have a look…
[continue…]
That's better.
Let's have a look… Well, your liver is bigger than I'd expect, but that's an occupational hazard, right? Apart from that, you're as healthy as a burer.
Can you refill my canteen with water?
Of course, merc. No problem. It'll cost you a thousand. The price may be high, but keep in mind that it's hard to filter out radiation out of water. What do you say?
Okay. Here's the canteen and money.
Nah. Changed my mind.
Let me hold on to your canteen for now; I'll fill it up later. In exchange, I'll give you this full canteen I have right here. When you run out of water again, come see me.
All right. Thanks.
I found a PDA belonging to this Final Day group… Wanna take a look at it?
Really? Is it encrypted?
Only partially.
I'll pay ten thousand for it. No more.
Sure, here you go.
Here's your cash, merc. Now let's take a look…
He's always alone; I doubt anybody hangs around him. I know his type like the back of my hand.
Where can I find him?
That's a bit more difficult. I have no idea where he went, but I might have a solution: I'll part with a beacon, you place it where I tell you, and then we'll be able to track him down.
All right. Give me that beacon.
Grab it from the storeroom and plant it on the bridge. I'll send you the exact coordinates on your PDA. Now go.
All right. I'll go get the beacon. Tell your guard to step aside.
Merc, don't forget that you need to set up that beacon before I can find where Klim's hiding.
Later.

Hey, merc. Let's get straight to business: I take it you already know that you were hired for more than one job, right? Good. Not only have I managed to make a lot of enemies in the long time I've been here, but there are many other things that need taking care of.\n \nBefore we begin, let's establish a few rules that will keep you and your men from getting into trouble: first of all, you know that stalker base by the railroad embankment? Don't go there, because Valerian despises mercenaries. Second, don't do any business behind my back. Third and final, all of this remains between us. Are we clear?
So, merc, have you found the flash drive yet?
Yeah. Here it is.
Not yet.
Excellent. Give it here. And don't bother me with the details… Tell me, though: the guy that was carrying it; is he dead?
Take the flash drive. And yeah. You won't have to worry about him ever again.
That's good to hear… And that son of a bitch thought he could rip me off. All right. Let's not waste any more time. You're free to go for now. I'll message you when I'll need you.
And now it's time to do your part of the deal. Give me the payment.
Hey, merc. Listen: I didn't call you for a job. I have a different offer for you instead.
Yeah? And what sort of offer would that be?
So, it's true what they say about you. I understand. Now hear out my only rule: I get paid on time right after the job is finished. No exceptions. Are we clear?
Well, I need you to send me two of your men to guard my bunker. I've been getting some extra heat recently; some people don't like the way I do business.
Sure. I could probably get you a couple of guards… depending on how much you'll pay.
Merc, have you forgotten that I've made a contract with your superiors? I can remind you the hard way. Either way, I want two guards near my bunker as soon as possible. You got that?
Not a chance. All my soldiers are already occupied. Besides, I'm not paying my leader with *my* money to hire *you* any security.
I don't loan cash!
You're right. I didn't call you for that… Did you hear about what happened last night?
No. What happened?

Something very strange… Last night, Valerian ran off somewhere with some of his most trusted men, and they haven't been seen since. His PDA has gone completely silent, and no one, not even in his own base, knows where he went.
Okay. And why are you telling me this?

I wanted to share the news with you, you know. Thought you might know something, but clearly, you don't. Either way, Orest will take over in the absence of Valerian. He's an experienced stalker who just came back from the Agroprom, and he'll be residing in the stalker base temporarily. I need you to deliver something to him. I've already talked to them; they'll let you into the base.
I'm not some delivery boy running around the Zone… If you don't have any *real* work, then I'll be on my way.
Listen here, you scoundrel: either you do as you're told or the contract will be canceled. Are we clear here?
Fine, trader. Give me the package and let's get this over with.

I hope we've cleared everything up.\n \nHere's the package. Give it to Orest personally. I told him you'd come. Also, Shaman was looking for you; he has a job for you. He's in the bar right now. Go and pay him a visit.
Bye.
I don't loan cash!
I don't loan cash!
Merc, don't forget that you need to set up that beacon before I can find this Klim guy.
All right. I'll go get it. Tell your guard to let me through.
Fine. I'll pay for your guys. Five thousand for both of them. No more.
That's better. I'll send them right away.
Thanks for the guards, merc! With this protection, I can rest easy.
I doubt you contacted me just to thank me.

We're clear. If we're on the same page, we can get on with your first assignment: a while back, a guy came in and wanted to sell me some valuable information, but the price he demanded for it was astronomical. And it wasn't even worth the price. The stalker's name is Klim, and he keeps the info in his flash drive. He always has it on him. Your job is to get me that flash drive and kill the stalker.
All right. What does this guy look like? Is he heavily armed?

No. He's just some random stalker with subpar gear. He wanted to play wise guy, and I won't let that slide. When he came here, all he had was sawed-off shotgun, and I doubt his assortment has improved since then.
Does he have any friends? Does he work in a group?
Tell me about yourself.

I always liked to work alone; by myself, for myself. But when I heard that the stalkers organized their own base, I knew I just had to join in. I've been in many places in the Zone, and to me, being among independent stalkers is the best. There are only regular stalkers here. You feel me? They don't have any codes, rules, or anything else that other factions have. They're just regular dudes trying to make a living, and that's the way it should be.
Good spare parts are very scarce in the Zone… How do you manage to work with what you have?

Well, it's not like I upgrade Gauss rifles over here, but I can manage to get some decent work done. I've been doing this for many years now, and I'm good at what I do. That's pretty much it. Most stalkers don't bring anything that complicated; mostly regular guns and armor that needs fixing. From time to time, a stalker asks for an upgrade to his suit or weapon, which I can carry out with ease. You can also take a look at what upgrades I can install. You might find that interesting.
From what I understand, you've traveled around the Zone quite a bit. Have you seen anything unusual on your trips?

Unusual? I came here from the Agroprom when the big emission hit; you know, the one that changed everything. The things that happened after can only be described as miracles. A place that was once totally empty became a total shitshow; part of the land there was all messed up with parts of it rising up—it was like a Salvador Dali painting—and the radiation there was so strong that you couldn't get anywhere near it without getting a lethal dose. Later on, the guys told me that the anomaly was one of the most dangerous in the Zone but that it had the rarest artifacts. If you ever find yourself near that area, beware…
Woah… Man, if it wasn't for you guys, we'd be dead right now! Raccoon and I are very grateful. It's a good thing you came by when you did… Who are you? Why did you risk your lives for us?
We're mercenaries. We were hired by Wolf to look for your squad. We found Zokhan, who gave us your location.
Zokhan's alive?! Oh, thank God! I thought these bastards killed him for sure; I'm really happy to hear that!… I want to ask you one more thing: where are you going now?
Don't worry. We'll escort you back to the rookie village. After that, we'll be on your way.
Good to hear. Those damn bandits took all of our gear, so we're left with nothing… and walking around in the Zone without a gun isn't exactly the smartest thing to do. So, are we heading out?
Hold on a sec. I need to talk to my partner.
Hold on a sec. Let me tell my guys where we're headed.
Yeah. Let's go.
Tell me about yourself.

I'm a trader… who's just starting out. When we came here not that long ago, Shaman said that everyone can be whoever they want. So I wanted to be a trader. I have the talent for this job; I've been buying and selling things since I was a kid. Back in school, I used sell those old electronic games; you know, the ones where there's a wolf that catches eggs? I'd hand them to my classmates for ten kopecks per game… I have a knack for it, you understand? Yeah, those were the days… Right now, I'm just trying to figure out how things work around here… I get most of my products from Sidorovich, so there's not that much profit, but hey: slowly but surely, I'm starting to get my own clients, so there's that.

Man, right now, we are living like in God's pocket… The military won't steal our loot anymore, so now all of our earnings will remain ours. After a deep raid, we can actually rest easy in the Cordon, and we can actually get a hold of some quality gear here. Hell, we can even start making real money. Not like before when the military would shake down a stalker the moment they spot one… Maybe one day, we will drive out these jarheads completely.
What do you think about the life in the Cordon right now?

Man, right now, we are living like in God's pocket… The military won't steal our loot anymore, so now all of our earnings will remain ours. After a deep raid, we can actually rest easy in the Cordon, and we can actually get a hold of some quality gear here. Hell, we can even start making real money. Not like before when the military would shake down a stalker the moment they spot one… Maybe one day, we will drive out these jarheads completely.
Fine. I won't tell anyone. What is it?

Usually, bandits don't poke their noses in that place, meaning that they had a special reason for being there. They must've been looking for something, and we ran into them by accident. Their behavior was also really strange; I saw one of them drop a blue notebook when they were there, and then I heard a few shots. After that, my vision went black, and when I woke up, I saw you. They must have taken the hostages and left.
Okay. And what do you suggest we do?
Could you go back there—where you found me—and look around again? Maybe you can find something. I have a feeling that those bandits were there for a reason. Don't worry; I'll pay up. You know me.
All right. I'll see what I can find.
I have better things to do than waste my time looking for something only God knows.
Merc, I'm counting on you here. Please; if you can, find some free time for this.
Fine… I'll go there and see what's what.
All right, but not right now.

You're back… Thank you. You saved those guys' lives. If not for you, they would've been dead; the bandits don't hold hostages for long. Also, thanks for the medkit. It truly saved my life. Was it hard facing off those scumbags?
So, Beast, have you finally found some time to help me out? I'll pay up good. You know me.
Fine… I'll go there and see what's what.
Fine… I'll go there and see what's what.
Hey, Beast. What's up?
Hey, Beast. Have you found the notebook?
Yeah. I found the notebook, and I lost twenty-five grand in the process. Now, I need that money back and your payment for the job, which will amount to thirty grand in total. Any questions?

Yeah. I found the notebook, and it held the coordinates of a meeting that was supposed to take place. Over there, I found a note that led me to the tunnel under the embankment. In the tunnel, I got jumped by some guy, and he demanded twenty-five grand from me, so I iced him.
What? How? What exactly happened?
It was easy. I'm used to these things.
There isn't that much to explain. I went to the tunnel and there was a bandit who tried to rob me, so I shot him down.

That's impossible. There's a stalker base nearby, so how would a bandit get anywhere near there? The bandits that hang around the northern checkpoint know full well not to go anywhere down south… This was done by someone else, I'm telling you. Did he tell you why he wanted twenty-five G's? And how the hell did you know to get to that tunnel anyway?

I found that notebook you mentioned before, and it contained the coordinates for a meeting. When I went to the meeting place, it was empty, save for a note that said someone would be waiting in tunnel at night. I went there, and it turned out to be a trap. The guy stuck a gun to my chest and demanded twenty-five grand for some case.
We need to see what's inside that case. Do you have it?

I have the case, but it's locked, and there's no way we're opening it without a professional lockpicker. Besides that, the case is really light, like it's empty… I doubt there's anything noteworthy inside.
All of this is very strange… I need the contents of that case. It might have some valuable info.
Fine. I'll take care of cracking the case. And you need to come up with the money that you owe me.
Hey, Beast. What's up?

That's impossible. There's a stalker base nearby, so why would a bandit go anywhere near there? The bandits that hang around the northern checkpoint know full well not to go anywhere down south… This was done by someone else, I'm telling you. Did he tell you why he wanted twenty-five G's? And how the hell did you know how to get to that tunnel anyway?

Too bad you guys didn't come by earlier; you would have saved a few more lives… Either way, though, you saved some lives today.\n \nHere, take this artifact. I found it in the Garbage. Never seen anything like it. I wanted to sell it to Sidorovich, but you've earned it.
That cash must've been payment for the case; the one he had on him.
We need to see what's inside that case. Do you have it?

I have the case, but it's locked, and there's no way we're opening it without a professional lockpicker. Besides that, the case is really light, like it's empty… I doubt there's anything noteworthy inside.
All of this is very strange… I need the contents of that case. It might have some valuable info.
Fine. I'll take care of cracking the case. I won't be giving away everything inside for free, though.
Hey, thanks, man. If you ever need my help, you know where to find me.
Hey, Beast. What's up?
Thanks. You said you needed to talk to me about something. Is it the reward?
No, Beast. I need to talk to you about something else, but you have to promise me that you'll keep it between us. All right?
Damn… Dude, I already told you everything I know… Please… Give me a medkit.
Thanks a ton, man… Whew. Feeling better already. You saved my life… Wait. Why are you here, anyway?
Wolf hired us to check up on your squad. I take it you're the only survivor?

No. Two of us were taken hostage by the bandit attackers. I heard one of them say they need hostages for something, but I don't know what the hell they're planning. I'm fairly sure our guys are still alive, though, so maybe there's still a chance to rescue them.
Where did they take them?
The northern checkpoint; the one that leads to the Garbage. They set up a small base and everything, the bastards.
Got it. We'll try to save them. You return to Wolf.
No… I can't just sit on my ass while my friends are in danger. I can shoot my gun, and I'm already feeling better.
Not a chance. Get back to Wolf. You're wounded, and you won't be of any use to us during the fight. We can handle a few bandits on our own, no problem.
Ugh… Fine. Just make sure you bring everyone back alive! I'm counting on you!
Go see Wolf and tell him what happened while we prepare the assault.
Dude, help me… I'm bleeding here. Please…
After you answer a few questions. Then I'll see what I can do.
Are you kidding me?… I… I can't hold out much longer… Gimme a medkit…
No. I'm serious. Tell me right now: who the hell are you, and where is Wolf's squad?

I'm Zokhan… As for the squad… you're looking at it… We were ambushed by bandits, and they killed everyone… They left me for dead… We… We managed kill a few of them… but it wasn't enough. There was too many of them… Dude, please, just give me a medkit.
All right. Here's your medkit.
I don't have any medkits… Sorry.
Uh-huh. It seems true to me.
First time I'm hearing about it.

It's a well-known fact by now that what we call “zombies” are just people who have completely lost their sanity and intelligence, and yet people still endanger their minds in hopes of finding better loot. That's human greed, all right. Duty, for example, doesn't even go anywhere near controllers, always keeping a kilometer between them and that dangerous mutant. They'd rather not risk their mental health; it's just not worth it.
Yeah, scary shit…
So a Freedom stalker heard about Duty's well known zoo…
Promising start…
