God knows what was going in that Freedomer's head, but he got into his mind that he must see those mutants that were held in the Duty zoo. Even though that guy was a good dude, it always seemed like he was too good. His honesty and loyalty had no limits, and it was clear that it was only a matter of time before he was about to do something really stupid. That's why nobody was really surprised when the stalker said he was going to infiltrate the Duty base and attempt to free those mutants.
What was he thinking?…

Since it was Freedom—the faction of the anarchists—as long as nobody does anything to harm the faction itself, everyone can do whatever they want. So they let the deluded Freedomer continue with his crazy plan. Everybody said their goodbyes to him, because they knew he was done for, but our hero wasn't as simple as he looked. I don't know how, but he managed to catch a live rodent so he could use it as “payment” for the ticket to Duty zoo. So what do you think Duty did?
I doubt they invited him over for tea…

I don't know whether it was because the guards were in a forgiving mood or because the Freedomer appeared totally harmless, but they let him through. However, when he finally got to Duty's zoo, shit hit the fan!

Too bad they couldn't enjoy their victory for long. They were struck by a psy-field! It's like the Brain Scorcher was a living creature that suddenly realized they were there and wanted to get rid of them. When the psy-field hit, only one of the guys was zombified. The other had a suit with a strong psy-protection system, so he managed to survive that wave while his friend's brains were fried for good. Some say this happens a lot; where not everyone gets zombified at once. The guy whose brains were intact tackled his friend and dragged him to the Red Forest in hopes of saving him…
Plot twists. That's good.

It turned out that the Freedomer was crazier than everyone thought. When he entered the zoo and saw the state the mutants were in, he lost his shit. The animals were locked in small cages with barely an inch to move, and they were so starved that they looked like scarecrows. The sight drove our hero mad, so he started screaming at the top of his lungs and jumped on the zoo keeper, Inquisitor, and started beating the shit out of him. At the same time, though, Inquisitor wanted to put their newly obtained rodent into the rodent cage, so its door was open! Once the Freedomer started assaulting him, all the rodents escaped. The Dutyers, of course, shot the Freedomer almost instantly…
Too bad… Poor fellow.

He did manage to follow through on his plan, though. He exchanged his own life for the freedom of those rodents who escaped. They ran between the soldier's legs without them noticing, until the rodents finally found their way out of the base.
Not a bad story, all right.

Did you hear about the village; the one near the army warehouses that's inhabited by bloodsuckers? Even though everyone knows about that hellhole, I bet you don't know why all the bloodsuckers flock there in first place.
Can't say that I do.

Way back before the big blowout that created the Zone, that village was inhabited by the military. Keep in mind, though, that these were no ordinary soldiers. They had some kind of different uniform with its own strange emblems. They were some type of special unit. No one knows for sure what their mission was, although it doesn't matter much for our story. Anyway, when the big blowout hit, almost all of the soldiers died instantly.
Sounds interesting, but what does this have to do with the bloodsuckers?

However, a few of those soldiers managed to survive in that same village by hiding inside the cellars, in which people used to store all the pickled goods in the old days… You know how our people are. We love our pickled shit, and we can't have enough of it.
I doubt he could accomplish anything, but that's some loyalty…
Well, they had to come out sooner or later, didn't they? They had to eat, after all. It's not like there was an unlimited supply of food in those cellars.

Yeah, you're right. They had to come out of there at some point, and they did. The soldiers would come out of the cellars from time to time to find some food and other supplies, grabbing whatever they could get their hands on. They didn't have any detectors, so they had no idea when they were walking through a radioactive field, and the amount of radiation they took was enormous. But they had no other choice due to food supplies running low.
Hell, I wouldn't know what to do either…

When they ran out of food completely, the soldiers resorted to cannibalism. What ensued was a total nightmare! Those guys were so starved that they ate the people who were too weak to go on; their own friends, no less. But that's not the crux of this story. Believe it or not, things get even weirder.
I've completely lost my appetite, and now you're telling me things are going to get even weirder… What else was I supposed to expect in the Zone?

Yeah. The Zone is an unpredictable place, and some even say that it's a living creature. In the Zone, some things don't die out, but rather adapt to it, revealing their ugliest form in the process. That's what happened to our beloved soldiers, who, instead of dying, turned into the bloodsuckers we now all know and love. The first generation of these mutants would wear a special soldier uniform; the same one as the guys that were stationed in the village. To this day, bloodsuckers flock to that place… Maybe they feel it's their home? Who the hell knows what goes on in the heads of those overgrown ticks…
Man, I don't even know what to say…

Yeah, trying to figure that out is a waste of time. Moral of the story, though, is that sometimes, it's better to just accept your death instead of turning into a complete monster. The latter is a fate much worse than death.
Yeah, maybe you're right… All right, I gotta go.
There was a time when the Barrier was totally unprotected and nobody was around to guard it.

Fate had more hardship in store for those two. All that noise attracted the attention of a Monolith squad that was patrolling the area and happened to see the two stalkers. They opened fire the second they noticed them.
I like stories about the old days, keep going.

Back then, huge waves of monsters would run through the Barrier and travel all the way to the Garbage. That's why most stalkers preferred not to set camp anywhere near the Barrier, and the farthest place you could see stalkers camping was in the bloodsucker village. But that village was no less dangerous, as it was always occupied by packs of… well, bloodsuckers. That's how the place got its name. Nobody really knows why those bloodsuckers flock to that village, but that's a story for another time… Back to what I was telling: because of the danger, stalkers would still in sleep in the houses of that village with one eye open.
Sounds like a story about me.

So, this one time, a certain screwball decided to spend the night on top of the tower located at the edge of the village. He climbed up, opened a bottle of vodka, and slowly started chugging it it whilst gradually falling asleep at the same time. Then, all of a sudden, he saw a human silhouette in the distance, rustling around in the bushes. The stalker at the tower grabbed his rifle and his binoculars and got in better position to take his shot. For all he knew, it could have been a bloodsucker or a snork looking for some fresh prey, or even worse: a controller. However, it turned out be a regular stalker who was looking for a place to sleep through night.
He got lucky…

Our hero was happy to see another stalker in the area, so he started throwing stuff from the top of the tower in hopes that the other guy would see him. The stalker wandering around the village finally realized what was going on and went straight to the tower. But was this wasn't an ordinary stalker. No, he was an experienced bandit with some serious gear.
Damn…

He was probably looking for a place where he could set up an ambush. Our hero wasn't beating around the bush, and the minute he saw it was a bandit, he opened fire on him. A serious firefight ensued between the two. The stalker threw a few grenades from the top of the tower, but the bandit was a tough one, and he avoided those grenades like a pro. After that, the two started shooting each other from behind cover, and the fight lasted for hours. Finally, after a long night of shooting, the bandit fell on the ground…
I am guessing the bandit was dead…

No matter how you spin, the stalker had a better position in that tower. After he shot down the bandit, he went down to check on the body. When he went inside the building the bandit was hiding in and saw the body, he froze from shock. It turned out that the bandit didn't die from a bullet. When they were busy shooting each other, a bloodsucker snuck in and broke the guy's neck. Before the stalker could even close his mouth, the bloodsucker killed him as well.
That was some luck out there.
The bloodsucker got a two for one deal.

If only those two would have just put their differences aside, they would have lived to fight another day. Instead of everyone going their own separate way in the morning, we could all just enjoy our time at a cozy campfire… But that's too much to ask for; we can't help but shoot at each other.
Hey, sometimes people can help. Just not in the Zone.
Man, have I got a weird story for you!
Things are weird enough already, but I guess it can't hurt.

A stalker went to the Zone to search for his beloved girl, who was known to the people of the Zone as The Snow Maiden. I don't know how she got that nickname. She was average in the looks department; nothing special. Although some say she had a nice personality. The guy looking for her, on the other hand, was a total scumbag, but that's how it usually is: the good ones always fall for the bad ones.
Yeah, I think we've all seen that happening.

The two finally found each other and went to the bloodsucker village. You know, the one near the army warehouses. Bloodsuckers would always flock to that place for some reason, but it was possible to survive there. That village had a group of stalkers there who would loot the dead bodies of veteran stalkers from unsuccessful assaults in the center of the Zone. A real bunch of assholes… The Snow Maiden and her boyfriend were members of said group. Despite the fact that the girl felt sick from the whole thing, she stayed, because she wanted to be with her boyfriend.
She was an idiot…

Hey, what can you do? You can't pick who you love. Anyway, one time, this band of looters had a disagreement about what loot to share. As for our heroine, it was the worst day of her life. The looters took out all of their frustration out on her by torturing and raping her. Thinking about it makes me sick. She was locked up in the water tower all day and night. However, strange things tend to happen in the Zone…

Just as it seemed the stalker and his friend were done for, things turned for the better. While the stalker was exchanging fire with the Monolith, his zombified friend stood up, and instead of attacking the stalker, he just stood and looked at him for a second, and after that, covered his friend from enemy fire with his own body, thus saving him. The Monolith were shocked when it happened! Zombified stalkers under the influence of the Brain Scorcher are supposed to be their allies; yet, this one wasn't!
Hopefully, it would be something that would aid our heroine. Poor woman, being tortured like that.

A controller had entered the village and he had killed the majority of the group in a matter of seconds. The few that remained climbed up the tower and barricaded themselves from within. That didn't help much, obviously. The controller broke through the barricade and slaughtered everyone inside, but do you know what's even weirder?
What?

The controller didn't touch the girl! It makes no sense, but that's what happened. He just left her there, and the horde of zombies following the controller didn't touch her either. Nobody can explain why that happened, but maybe the Zone decided to save the girl. Either way, it's a true miracle.
I'm at a loss for words…
The only thing we can know for sure is that this forsaken place doesn't just destroy people, but it helps the poor and the tormented from time to time. Still, it is a mystery how the Zone works.
Risking your life for answers isn't always the best solution. Some things are meant to remain a mystery.
Sorry, I don't have anything interesting right now… I… I ran out of stories… Awkward, right?
Yeah, that is very unlikely.

The zombie just kept covering his friend while his buddy was crawling towards the trees. When the stalker got to the tree, they looked at each other for a second, and they both knew it was their last moment together. The stalker ran away and managed to get back to the Barrier. Since then, that stalker never harms any zombies, but instead just passes them by.
Yeah, I understand that.
As for his zombified friend, some say that he wanders around radioactive forests to this day and protects any lost stalkers he comes across. And that meeting him is a sign of great fortune to come.

Hello, good sir. What brings you here? Everyone calls me Storyteller, because I like to tell various stories from all across the Zone, with a bottle of vodka in my hand. If you give me a bottle, I might just tell you something interesting.
Even though the story ended with a bit of hope, it was still very depressing. Well, I've got to go.

There are some people who have special talents and abilities out there. There was a stalker here who was completely immune to psy-emissions. He could walk right through fields with out a scratch whilst others would lose their minds.
Let's say that's somehow possible…

One might think that this stalker was some kind of a zombie, but that couldn't be further from the truth. In reality, this stalker was actually clever, and used his gift well. He respected the Zone's boundaries, and he would never go to places he wasn't supposed to. Sometimes, he wouldn't go past the Brain Scorcher at all despite being able to without taking any damage. He would bring unique artifacts from his raids into places others have never been to, which would earn him a lot of money. He never hesitated to help out a fellow stalker, and so earned respect of most people, even though he had his fair share of enemies. But he was a good fighter too, and he always had good gear on hand. Most people just avoided getting into a fight with him.
Go on…

He was also very cautious. Despite being well equipped, he would rather stay away from conflict. That's why he made camp in one of the abandoned hangars in Yantar. The psy-emissions there were on full throttle, and anybody who would go there would become zombified in the flick of a switch; unless it was our guy, of course. I have no idea how he protected himself from the wandering mutants and zombies, though. But he lived there pretty quietly.
Seems the guy was living a good life…

Everything would have been good and well, except one time, a controller came to those same hangars. Of course, try as it might, the controller couldn't take control of the stalker, but it still made his life miserable. Nobody knew for sure what went down there… He only mentioned his problem a few times, saying he tried to kill the controller a few times, but that it got away. That's not the main point of the story, though…
What's the point, then? I'm dying to know here…

At a later point in time, a group of experienced stalkers was moving through Yantar, and they ran into that same controller! They were all good fighters, so they decided to get rid of the creature for good. They carefully backed the controller into a corner, and you know what happened then? That same stalker who was living in Yantar started shooting at the group from his sniper rifle. He managed to kill half of them, and the rest escaped. No one knows why he did it…
All right. Here's a bottle. Tell me something interesting…
That stalker must've lost his mind.

The stalkers who traveled to Yantar have told stories about those two. They said that, even though the controller and that stalker were at each other's throats all day, they would protect each other when there was an outside threat. Nobody could find an explanation as to why this was happening, and thus it was just considered another mystery in the Zone. After a while, the duo disappeared somewhere, and nobody has seen either one of them since.
A mystery indeed. I don't even know what to think.
Here's what I think: If you have a nemesis who you've had a conflict with for a very long time, then you get used to them, and then ending that relationship becomes very difficult.
I doubt that's the case, but it's possible.
I'll tell you a story. Not necessarily scary, but it's definitely creepy. I take it you've heard about the “concentration camp” down in the Garbage?
Yeah, I've heard about it.

I'll tell you what: the Garbage was always a god-awful place. Even back before the incident in '86, the place was used as a dump where all the unneeded radioactive waste was thrown and buried. Near every junk heap, there was a station where the workers would dump the trash. However, the only station that I still remember to this day is the one we call the junkyard. Many people died there due to various accidents, and those that didn't were too afraid to talk about it, fearing that they would themselves be killed in an accident for talking too much. That's why you don't really hear about it. Anyway, after the incident at the CNPP, the Garbage was just left like that, with all the junk and tools intact…
Go on…

Even back then, there were death traps on every corner: ammunition exploding, gasoline in cars catching fire, sometimes even huge metal parts fell on workers from out of nowhere, killing them. Nobody could explain what was happening.
I'm not in the mood for stories.
Okay…

When the Zone emerged, everyone flocked to the Garbage immediately, either just for the artifacts or because it was a good strategic point. At first, Duty tried to take over the place and make it a safe haven for regular stalkers, getting rid of mutants and such. They would also deal with any bandits who were robbing or murdering passing stalkers.
That's very decent of them.

Only, it didn't last for long. Duty made a small base inside an old bunker and would hide there during blowouts. Only, one time, when a blowout was coming, they all ran inside their bunker to wait it out, only to find out they were trapped. The blowout changed the positions of all the anomalies in such a way that they would block off every entrance to the bunker. All the Duty members there died of starvation.
That's a brutal way to die. Wouldn't wish it on my worst enemy.

What followed was no less brutal. At first, Freedom tried to make a base in the Garbage, but the constant mutant attacks at night prevented them from doing so. Regular loner stalkers also tried to establish something of a base for anyone who was coming back from a long raid to the Zone and needed to quickly resupply, get some sleep, or to sell off some unneeded gear. But like everyone else, they didn't last for very long. One guy came back with a mutated virus that he caught somewhere deep in the Zone. Even though the stalkers figured out quickly that an epidemic was among them, the base still had to be turned into a quarantine area where no one could get in or out. As for the sick, they all died there.
Fucking horrifying…

Yeah… No matter what happened or who came over to this to the giant dumpster, it always ended badly. As of now, the bandits are occupying the Garbage and the junkyard they call the “concentration camp.” Little do they know that the ones who are going to die soon are not only the stalkers they are holding prisoners but they themselves as well. They're total assholes, but I still feel sorry for them… They are people, after all.
Sure… All right, gotta go.

Even though women aren't exactly common in the Zone and most stalkers only catch glimpses of them in porn mags, you can encounter a woman here from time to time. Not that you can expect anything good from them coming here; only problems. I have a story about a woman stalker…
All right, I'm listening.

The Garbage—which is now controlled by bandits—was once a place where experienced stalkers would go to get some rest after a long journey and resupply. The trader there was a chick named Matryona. She would sell gear and food to those same stalkers. Although her prices were through the roof, that only scared off the rookies. Other than that, though, her business was doing very well, and she would always cash out with a smile on her face. But under that big smile was a very staunch alcoholic… She would empty multiple bottles of vodka a day.
A guilty conscience, perhaps?

Anyways, one time, a guy was unlucky enough to fall in love with her. He ran after her all day and night, bringing her gifts and shit… Sometimes, he would even serenade her with his guitar during the evenings. It annoyed everyone else; they made him wrap it up quickly. It was obvious that the guy was totally obsessed with her.
Yeah. Not the first time I'm hearing about a guy losing his head over a chick… What about Matryona?

She would only wink at him from time to time with her green eyes and milk him for all his goods. Everyone felt sick just watching it; even the bandits felt bad for the guy. But what can you do to help a guy in a situation like that? Not much. Everyone just shook their heads and waited until the mess would reach its awful conclusion.
So what was the conclusion?

Things ended badly. One time, she was drunk as usual, wandering around in the Garbage, but the thing was, she was so drunk she couldn't even see a vortex right in front of her. She couldn't even realize what was going on before the anomaly ripped her to shreds.
Can't feel much sympathy for her… What about our Romeo?

He completely lost his mind. He wanted to find the Wish Granter and wish her back, so he went past the Barrier. After a while, a few Freedomers saw his zombified ass marching back from the Barrier alongside a Monolith squad and some other zombies. All that was left of him was a shell of all of his humanity drained from him, like anyone else who tried to go past the Barrier before him.
Hello, young man. If you share a bottle of vodka with me, I'll tell you an interesting story.
Yeah, poor guy. All right, I'll be on my way.
I'll tell you a story about two guys who met up in the “concentration camp” in the Garbage.
I'm all ears.

The stalkers who end up in the concentration camp are usually those who have enough courage to visit the Garbage but not enough money to pay the bandits. Because these stalkers can't pay their “debt” for entering the bandits' territory, they're forced to work their asses off looking for anything valuable in the junk heaps. This, of course, stops eventually, when the bandits decide to kill their prisoners off. To this day, that death prison is full of stalkers who didn't have enough money to pay off the bandits. However, one time, two individuals met up inside that camp. If they were anywhere else, they'd just be fighting each other…
Go on…

The two dudes that I'm talking about were a Dutyer and a Freedomer! I don't know why nobody was sent to rescue them. Perhaps it was because everyone thought they were dead or something. It's not that hard to believe, considering how many people go missing in the Zone every day. But that's not the gist of this story…
So what is it?

Those two decided to put their differences aside and plan an escape. They were the only two capable stalkers in the camp, and nobody expected that they would help each other. Strangely enough, they managed to form a pretty tight bond between each other… After a while of planning, the duo managed to escape from the bandits while they were doing another one of their archaeological digs.
So how did they manage to escape?

I don't know for sure, but I heard that they used an artifact as weapon. They found it in one of the junk piles and did something to it that made it turn into an anomaly. They say that if you spin an artifact in your hand the right way and poke it in the right places, it will turn into an anomaly in which it was created. I can't say for sure because I have no idea how to do that, but I do know people who are experts in artifact handling.
I have a cool story for you. It starts with two good friends going into the Red Forest to look for very rare artifacts and to hunt some big game.
That's too bad…

Anyway, both of them managed to escape and ran off to the nearest Freedom outpost. They could see the light at the end of the tunnel, but alas, fate played a cruel trick on them. A Freedom sniper saw the Dutyer and took him out with one shot, a real tragedy. The Freedomer was devastated, and instead of running further away from the bandits, he just sat there crying and mourning his dead friend while the bandits were getting closer and closer. But you know what happened then?
Stop making me guess. Just tell me.

Everyone died except for the Freedomer who was on the run. The bandits and the Freedomers at the outpost started fighting until they killed each other while our escapee was weeping over his dead friend. When the smoke cleared, everyone was dead expect for him. I guess the Zone spared him for some reason. After that, he left Freedom and became a total hermit who now spends his time exploring caves and other abandoned places in the Zone. Who knew things would turn out this way…
Yeah… Anyway, I got to go.
Have you heard anything about the Duty zoo?
Not much. I know it exists, but that's about it.

It's a really weird and creepy place. Stuffed mutant carcasses gawk at you with their empty eyes, all lined up one after the other. The guy who organized this zoo, Inquisitor, isn't exactly normal as well, as one might guess. I don't know how much you know about that zoo, but I bet you don't how and why that guy organized that zoo in the first place.
All right, then. Tell me.

Legend has it he had a very expensive old watch gifted to him either by his granddad or great granddad. I don't know for sure how he got that watch, but it's not that important. What's important is that this watch was very valuable, and therefore, the Inquisitor would carry this small little personal treasure with him at all times so that no one could steal it.
Great start.
What does this have to do with the zoo, exactly?

If you would stop interrupting, I would explain. So, one time, the guy ran into a bloodsucker in some forest, and he barely managed to fight it off. He survived, but so did the bloodsucker. Though, it managed to drag away the Inquisitor's watch in his teeth… Or rather his tentacles… Or even swallowed it whole… Heh, who knows… Either way, the Inquisitor lost his most valuable item that day.
That's kind of funny…

He got really pissed that time; spent a few days with his shotgun searching for his lost watch. He was so angry he committed a bloodsucker genocide; killed at least a dozen bloodsuckers and sliced each of them open in hope of finding his lost wristwatch. He couldn't find anything, though, no matter how many he tracked down and killed.
Shit happens…

However, since then, that guy had developed a knack for capturing and dissecting mutants. It's like he found some kind of a hidden talent. Some say that, to this day, he's looking for his lost watch, but no one knows for sure.
You know, if he would've put out a decent reward for that watch, then stalkers would've found it in no time.

Well, after all these years, I do know for sure that sometimes, the bad things in life are fate's way of setting us on the right path. Just like the Inquisitor, who, after losing his watch, instead found his new talent.
I doubt that. Bad shit happens to me all the time, and it hasn't yielded any benefit.
Have you ever been to the Duty zoo?

They got pretty far, and they've collected a lot of good loot along the way, but greed got the better of them and they decided to keep pushing further. They went further, inch by inch, until, suddenly, they wandered right into the Brain Scorcher! You can be sure that those two were paralyzed from fear when they saw those antennas over the horizon…
I've heard about it…

It doesn't matter that much, to be honest. The important part is that the zoo doesn't have a controller's stump in it, and by the looks of it all, it never will. Obtaining the intact body of a controller is just way too dangerous, and there's no way the general will allow to hunt such thing after the last incident.
So what's the point of this story?

The point is that, one time, Duty tried to obtain an intact carcass of a controller; the first one they could find. They wanted to shoot him with a sniper rifle between the eyes, thus leaving most of his body intact. They knew of a controller lair not far from their base in a nearby forest. The mutant was living in a small cave, and it would only come out at night to hunt for food. So the Dutyers decide it's an easy target and sniping it from far away wouldn't be a problem.
Yeah, I've hunted a few controllers for a few clients.

Then a squad of Duty soldiers made camp on top of a small hill not far from the controller's lair. Their plan was simple: wait for the controller to come out of his cave and then have the sniper shoot in the head. However, despite them waiting for a few days straight, the controller didn't come out of his lair; it's like he knew they were there. Slowly but surely, the squad was running out of food and water; however, the Dutyers didn't want get back to base empty-handed, so they decided to advance closer to the lair and try to lure the controller out.
Bad move.

That's for sure. They couldn't get into position in time when the controlled popped out. The poor bastards had their minds broken… The controller turned out to be an experienced one, and could easily sense that he was being watched by a group of stalkers. Everyone was zombified except for one guy who barely managed to escape, and even *he* suffered some serious brain damage. Since that hunting trip, that guy can't even speak normally. He constantly stutters; can't even finish a sentence.
Well, we all have our battle scars.

The gist of this story is that one of the stalkers that were zombified on that hunting trip was the brother of Krylov, the founder of Duty! When Krylov found about this, he strictly prohibited anybody from going anywhere in that lair. Truth is, Krylov doesn't want anyone killing his brother, because he's hoping that one day, the scientists can find the cure for zombification and save his sibling.
I'm here for the tools.
What about them?
I used to bring tools for Van.
Well, I don't have everything I need. If you find anything, bring it here.
All right.
I brought some tools.
Great… So, which ones are for me?
The ones for basic work.
Great! Now I just need tools for fine work and calibration…
The ones for fine work.
Great! Now I just need tools for basic work and calibration…
The ones for calibration.
Great! Now I just need tools for basic work and also ones for finer work…
Nothing yet.
Awesome! Now if you'd bring tools for calibration, I'd be all set.
Awesome! Now if you'd bring tools for fine work, I'd be all set.
Awesome! Now if you'd bring tools for basic work, I'd be all set.
Wow! Where the hell did you find them?
If you need any tools, I can get them.

That would be awesome. At the moment, it's like working in the Stone Age. The only difference is that the soldering iron has replaced the shaman's staff… If I had tools, I could do some top upgrades, and you better believe there'd be coin in it for you, too…
Okay. I'll look for them.
I've changed my mind.
Good idea. I can do upgrades and you can earn cash…
Hey, you still need those tools?
Of course I do! Show me what you got.
I've got tools for basic work.
Great. Now I can start modifying weapons and armors.
I've got tools for fine work.
Great. Now I can start working on advanced upgrades.
I've got tools for calibration.
Excellent! Now I can turn your guns into killing machines… Ones that would put Sidorovich at your mercy. He he.
Nothing yet.
Sidorovich, turn off the radio.
All right. I'm sick of it myself.
Sure. What, you've got a headache?
What, you don't like my music? So be it.
Sidorovich, turn on the radio.
You want some music? Sure, here you go.
All right. I'm also in the mood for some music.
Sure, here you go. Listen to your heart's content.
Anything interesting around here?

Not really. This place is mostly for rookies and people who come back from long trips looking to sell their loot. There's the army outpost south of here, so beware of them. North of here, there's a road leading to the Garbage.
Tell me about the rookie village.

There's not much to say. This is where most rookies start off, but after gaining some money and experience, they move further north. This place is sort of the main starting point for stalkers. Once they gain some experience and can earn a bit of cash, they move up north. There are some idiots who stay here because they can't handle themselves anywhere else in the Zone, but that's about it. From time to time, you can see an experienced stalker walking through here to sell their loot to Sidorovich and to get some rest in a quiet place.
How about the military? Do they give you any trouble?

Not really. We have a non-verbal agreement: we don't bother them and they don't bother us. They say themselves that they'd rather not risk their lives fighting with stalkers who will mostly likely die in anomalies anyway. And it's the same for us: we'd rather not get in their way. When the military is on a raid or looking for something, we stay out of their way and let them do their job.
Tell me about Sidorovich.

He is the go-to trader in the Cordon. His main clients are rookies and newcomers to the Zone. He has a lot of connections in and out of the Zone. They say he started trading in his youth, selling in college. He's highly respected by stalkers for his honest business, but at the same time, he's disliked for his greed and selfishness. One thing's for sure: he's given a lot of stalkers an opportunity to survive, and without him, they would probably be dead. He also has the richest business in Zone. If Sidorovich doesn't have something, then you're not going to find it anywhere else.
Tell me about yourself.

I'm sort of the leader here. I teach the rookies how to live and survive in the Zone. As for why I'm here, I had enough time to wander around the Zone, and I'm sick of it. I came here to the Cordon to leave the Zone a long time ago, but since then, something's been holding me here. Like I'm under a spell or something. Every time I try to leave, something gets in the way; either the military is doing a raid or a blowout starts at the wrong time. Sometimes, I get offered a job so good, I can't refuse it.
Tell me about this place.

Right now, we're in the Cordon. Down south, there's an army outpost, guarding the entrance to the Zone. Further north, there's a road leading to the Garbage. This place still somewhat resembles the outside world, since there are barely any artifacts or anomalies here. You can see some wild boars or dogs here every now and then, but other than that, it's totally quiet. Well… Quiet in comparison with the rest of the Zone, that is.

This place is mostly for rookies and people who come back from long trips looking to sell their loot. There's the army outpost south of here, so beware of them. North of here, there's a road leading to the Garbage.
Lead the way.
